CORE ICP PROFILE
“The High-Stakes Corporate Cohort Decision Maker”
This ICP represents US-based L&D Managers, Heads of Training, and Program Directors within corporations, medical institutions, financial organizations, and leadership development firms who run cohort-style leadership and enablement training programs. These are not small one-off sessions. They are structured, high-visibility programs with 50–150+ participants, often delivered over long periods of time in full cohorts of 6–12+ sessions or ongoing training cycles. Many of these organizations, such as Contemporary Leadership Advisors or The Peopleside, “shop” and deliver leadership development products at scale, where consistency and professionalism directly impact future contracts.

Their programs typically run on Zoom, Microsoft Teams, Webex, or mixed corporate platforms depending on client requirements. They frequently incorporate breakout rooms, polling, embedded videos, music, and other interactive elements to enhance learning. As cohorts grow larger or extend over multiple sessions, the production becomes “too important to risk doing alone,” especially when interactivity and functionality must work smoothly without interruption.

In their own words, the problem is that “my facilitators have to do too much at the same time.” They are forced to focus on both the technical side and the teaching side, and “usually the teaching side suffers.” When these programs run without a dedicated producer, facilitators feel overwhelmed. Technical issues arise, screen sharing fails, music doesn’t play, breakout rooms don’t open properly, and there is no dedicated person to troubleshoot issues as they happen. The underlying cost of a bad session is not just inconvenience; it’s “professional trust and credibility of future programming.”

Most of these decision-makers have already tried managing it themselves or relying on cheaper internal IT support. They hesitate to invest because they believe “you can do it all yourself,” or they worry about budget. Some fear technical failure or “loss of control of the space,” or are concerned about working with someone the facilitator hasn’t built rapport with. However, the turning point usually comes when they understand that the producer’s role is to ensure “technology is never a barrier to the learning” so they can “do what they do best.” When they realize they can focus exclusively on audience interactivity while a reliable, consistent production team handles the platform, they opt in for the peace of mind that comes from knowing the experience will run smoothly every time.

4. PSYCHOLOGY PROFILE
Their Internal Struggle
They are not thinking:
“We need a producer.”
They are thinking:
“My facilitators are juggling too much.”
“My instructors can’t focus fully on delivery.”
“We keep managing tech and teaching at the same time.”
That is our opening.
Their Real Fear
Not money.
Not tech.
The real fear is:
Loss of professional credibility.
If something goes wrong:
Breakout rooms fail
Audio glitches
Screen share dies
Facilitator freezes
Participants confused
The damage is:
Trust erosion.
In corporate training, trust = future contracts.
Emotional Drivers
They want:
Peace of mind.
Control.
Stability.
Predictability.
Consistency across sessions.
They want to feel:
“We’ve got this handled.”
5. THEIR CURRENT BEHAVIOR
What they try before hiring:
Managing internally
Using IT support
Having facilitators self-manage
Doing rehearsals only
Belief they hold:
“We can handle it ourselves.”
Assumption to attack:
“That you can do it all yourself.”
That’s our core ad test.
6. MOMENT OF CONVERSION
The shift happens when they realize:
“If I focus on teaching and someone else handles tech, the learning improves.”
That’s the pivot.
Our ad must trigger:
“You do what you do best. We ensure tech is never the barrier.”
That line is powerful.

8. ATTACK ANGLES FOR ADS
Angle 1 – Cognitive Overload
“Your facilitators are doing two jobs at once.”
List:
• Teaching
• Managing chat
• Launching polls
• Opening breakout rooms
• Troubleshooting
• Watching timing
Message:
Teaching suffers when tech becomes a distraction.
Angle 2 – Professional Risk
“If your virtual classroom glitches, credibility drops instantly.”
For medical and financial organizations, this hits hard.
Use words like:
Professional trust
Credibility
Standards
Reputation
Consistency
Angle 3 – Interactivity Failure
“You want interactivity, breakout rooms, polls, smooth transitions, but without chaos.”
He specifically mentioned:
Breakout rooms
Polling
Videos
Music
Smooth functionality
Lean into this.
Angle 4 – Scale Pressure
“Small sessions can survive improvisation. 100+ participant cohorts cannot.”
This filters properly.

11. OBJECTION HANDLING
Objection 1: “We can do it ourselves.”
Response angle:
“You can. But should your facilitator manage 7 tasks simultaneously during a $40k program?”
Objection 2: Budget
Reframe:
“What does one failed cohort cost in future renewals?”
Objection 3: Rapport concerns
He mentioned fear of working with someone facilitators don’t know.
So messaging must emphasize:
Consistency.
Reliable recurring team.
Pre-session alignment.
Rehearsal integration.

13. SALES CALL STRATEGY FOR HIM
He must ask:
How many participants?
How many sessions?
What’s at stake?

Then position:

Ideal Client Snapshot:
US-based L&D or Program Director running 50–150+ participant cohort-based corporate training programs in medical, financial, or enterprise environments, who values credibility, structured delivery, and facilitator focus, and is willing to invest $20k+ for reliable, professional virtual classroom production support.
This is the profile.
Everything in our ads and landing must revolve around:
